results.title: For all practical purposes. Statistics. 2
results.brief_description: Behind the headlines In this episode Sol Garfunkel looks in greater detail at sampling methods for collecting statistical data. Examples include employment surveys done by the Bureau of Statistics and medical tests on the effect of aspirin on the incidence of heart disease.

results.title: For all practical purposes. Statistics. 1
results.brief_description: Overview Sol Garfunkel introduces us to the science of statistics and the manner in which it permeates our daily lives, from baseball to politics, to medical tests and gambling. The outcome of a single event may be unpredictable, but the outcome of many events is very predictable and this identification of patterns is what statistics is all about. He also introduces ways of collecting data, and in particular how sampling should be done.

results.title: For all practical purposes. Social choice. 5
results.brief_description: The Prisoner’s dilemma is a mathematical game which illustrates the dilemma at the root of the arms race. Game theory is used in politics and business and many other areas which involve conflict to identify which strategies to use and the potential outcomes of these strategies. In the prisoner’s dilemma, two players have to decide whether to be loyal or to betray the other. Individual self-interest, if chosen by each player can lead to the worst result for both players, whereas loyalty can produce a compromise solution. The program also looks at “Chicken” a game of confrontation and a repeated “Prisoner’s dilemma”.

results.title: For all practical purposes. Social choice. 4
results.brief_description: This program entitled “Zero sum games: games of conflict” deals with strategies employed by parties with conflicting needs, requiring decision-making. Optimal strategies (pure and mixed) are described mathematically with game matrices explained. Presented by Sol Garfunkel.

results.title: For all practical purposes. Social choice. 3
results.brief_description: A Problem of fair division This video deals with fair division problems, using the example of sharing a cake between seven people and through various proportional representation electoral systems. There is an impossibility theorem that states that there is no perfect method of apportionment. Weighted voting systems do not solve the problem, which leads to a discussion of who has power in government. The Banzhof power index is demonstrated.

results.title: For all practical purposes. Social choice. 2
results.brief_description: The Impossible dream is the search for the perfect voting method. This program describes 5 different methods of voting, and dramatises their operation with an election involving five different candidates. Each voting method results in a different candidate being elected, thus demonstrating Kenneth Arrow’s impossibility theorem which states that no voting method can satisfy fairness criteria. The voting methods demonstrated are: Plurality method, Plurality with runoff, Sequential runoff, Borda count and the Condorcet method.

results.title: For all practical purposes. Social choice. 1
results.brief_description: Overview This module will be looking at the mathematics of decision making and gives an overview of the field by looking at game theory and some examples of mathematical games, such as zero sum games, prisoner’s dilemma and tragedy of the commons. The program then looks at different voting systems and how to work out the fairest method of voting.

results.title: For all practical purposes. On size and shape. 5
results.brief_description: It started in Greece In this program Sol Garfunkel looks at the beginnings of mathematics and in particular of geometry and trigonometry, in ancient Greece. In particular he discusses Euclid and his techniques to measure spatial relationships which form the basis of Euclidean geometry. He then moves to discussing how distances can be calculated using triangles, and the discoveries of Thales and Pythagoras, which leads to a discussion of the development of trigonometry and Aristothanes. He concludes with a brief look at non-Euclidean geometries, such as Elliptic geometry and Hyperbolic geometry.

results.title: For all practical purposes. On size and shape. 4
results.brief_description: The Stand up conic Using the circus as an illustration, Sol Garfunkel looks at conic sections - the circle, the ellipse, the parabola and the hyperbola. He also looks at some practical applications of these geometric forms, as in aeroplane wings, elliptical chain wheels on bicycles, the Mormon tabernacle dome, headlamps, telescopes and bridges, as well as discussing the history of the conic sections from Appolonius and Ptolomy to Keppler’s laws of planetary motion and Newton’s Principia.

results.title: For all practical purposes. On size and shape. 3
results.creator_credit: COMAP, Chedd-Angier Productions and Olga Rakich
results.brief_description: It grows and grows explores the mathematical concept of geometric growth, by looking at compound interest, and how to calculate the maximum sustainable yield of fish. The program discusses limiting values, reproduction curves, population pyramids and explains the formulae used for calculating these.
